speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, the FOMC kept interest rates near zero and, in light of the progress the economy has made toward our goals, decided to begin reducing the pace of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With these actions, monetary policy will continue to provide strong support to the economic recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Given the unprecedented nature of the disruptions related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy, we remain attentive to risks and will ensure that our policy is well positioned to address the full range of plausible economic outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say more about our monetary policy decisions after reviewing recent economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Economic activity expanded at a 6.5 percent pace in the first half of the year, reflecting progress on vaccinations, the reopening of the economy, and strong policy support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the third quarter, real GDP growth slowed notably from this rapid pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The summer’s surge in COVID cases from the Delta variant has held back the recovery in the sectors most adversely affected by the pandemic, including travel and leisure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity has also been restrained by supply constraints and bottlenecks, notably in the motor vehicle industry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, both household spending and business investment flattened out last quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, aggregate demand has been very strong this year, buoyed by fiscal and monetary policy support and the healthy financial positions of households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With COVID case counts receding further and progress on vaccinations, economic growth should pick up this quarter, resulting in strong growth for the year as a whole.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Conditions in the labor market have continued to improve, and demand for workers remains very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement slowed with the rise in COVID cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In August and September, job gains averaged 280,000 per month, down from an average of about 1 million jobs per month in June and July.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The slowdown has been concentrated in sectors most sensitive to the pandemic, including leisure and hospitality and education.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate was 4.8 percent in September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This figure understates the shortfall in employment, particularly as participation in the labor market remains subdued.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of the softness in participation likely reflects the aging of the population and retirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But participation for prime-aged individuals also remains well below pre-pandemic levels—in part reflecting factors related to the pandemic, such as caregiving needs and ongoing concerns about the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, employers are having difficulties filling job openings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These impediments to labor supply should diminish with further progress on containing the virus—supporting gains in employment and economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy have contributed to sizable price increases in some sectors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, bottlenecks and supply chain disruptions are limiting how quickly production can respond to the rebound in demand in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, overall inflation is running well above our 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Supply constraints have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, it remains the case that the drivers of higher inflation have been predominantly November 3, 2021 connected to the dislocations caused by the pandemic—specifically, the effects on supply and Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL demand from the shutdown, the uneven reopening, and the ongoing effects of the virus itself.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand the difficulties that high inflation poses for individuals and families, particularly those with limited means to absorb higher prices for essentials such as food and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our tools cannot ease supply constraints.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Like most forecasters, we continue to believe that our dynamic economy will adjust to the supply and demand imbalances and that, as it does, inflation will decline to levels much closer to our 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, it is very difficult to predict the persistence of supply constraints or their effects on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Global supply chains are complex; they will return to normal function, but the timing of that is highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to our longer-run goal of 2 percent inflation and to having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at this goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we were to see signs that the path of inflation, or [of] longer-term inflation expectations, was moving materially and persistently beyond levels consistent with our goal, we would use our tools to preserve price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will be watching carefully to see whether the economy is evolving in line with expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s policy actions have been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our asset purchases have been a critical tool.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They helped preserve financial stability early in the pandemic and since then have helped foster smooth market functioning and accommodative financial conditions to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Last December, the Committee stated its intention to continue asset purchases at a pace of at least $120 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our November 3, 2021 maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee judged that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the economy has met this test, and decided to begin reducing the pace of its asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Beginning later this month, we will reduce the monthly pace of our net asset purchases by $10 billion for Treasury securities and $5 billion for agency mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also announced another reduction of this size in the monthly purchase pace starting in mid-December, since that month’s purchase schedule will be released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York prior to our December FOMC meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If the economy evolves broadly as expected, we judge that similar reductions in the pace of net asset purchases will likely be appropriate each month, implying that increases in our securities holdings would cease by the middle of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, we are prepared to adjust the pace of purchases if warranted by changes in the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even after our balance sheet stops expanding, our holdings of securities will continue to support accommodative financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decision today to begin tapering our asset purchases does not imply any direct signal regarding our interest rate policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to articulate a different and more stringent test for the economic conditions that would need to be met before raising the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to complete the recovery in employment and achieve our price-stability goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say it this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try to focus on what we can control—and that is how to communicate as clearly as possible, in this highly uncertain world, how we’re thinking about the economic outlook and the balance of risks and how policy will evolve in that case and also in the cases, which are frequent, where the economy evolves in unexpected ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the focus at this meeting is on tapering asset purchases, not on raising rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is time to taper, we think, because the economy has achieved substantial further progress toward our goals, measured from last December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think it’s time yet to raise interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is still ground to cover to reach maximum employment, both in terms of employment and in terms of participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Getting to your question, our baseline expectation is that supply bottlenecks and shortages will persist well into next year, and elevated inflation as well, and that, as the pandemic subsides, supply chain bottlenecks will abate—and job growth will move back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as that happens, inflation will decline from today’s elevated levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the timing of that is highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, certainly, we should see inflation moving down by the second or third quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The time for lifting rates and beginning to remove accommodation will depend on the path of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think we can be patient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If a response is called for, we will not hesitate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what I will tell you is, we will be watching carefully to see whether the economy evolves in line with our expectations, and policy will adapt appropriately.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at the progress that we’ve made over the course of the last year, if that pace were to continue, then the answer would be: “Yes, I do think that that is possible.” Of course, we measure maximum employment based on a wide range of figures, but it’s certainly within the realm of possibility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, in real terms, they’ve been—they had been running a little bit below inflation, so real wages were not really increasing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, with the ECI reading, it becomes close to maybe not increasing, but close to back to zero in terms of the real increase.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the concern is a somewhat unusual case where, if wages were to be rising persistently and materially above inflation and productivity gains, that could put upward pressure on, or downward pressure on margins and cause companies to—or employers, really—to raise prices as a result, and you can see yourself, find yourself in what we used to call a wage–price spiral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that, at this point, we don’t see Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL troubling increases in wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, so, you know, this isn’t the traditional Phillips curve situation where there’s a direct tradeoff, where that’s really what we’re talking about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, in this situation, we do have a provision in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals, as you know, that says when those two things are in tension, what we do is, we take into account the employment shortfalls and inflation deviations and the potentially different time horizons over which employment and inflation are projected to return to levels judged consistent with the mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we used to call that the “balanced approach” paragraph.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to think about the amount of the deviation, we have to think about the time it will take, and we have to make policy in a world where the two goals are in tension.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what it really boils down to is something that’s common sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is risk management.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to be aware of the risks that we’re—particularly now the risk of significantly higher inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see shortages and bottlenecks persisting into next year, well into next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see higher inflation persisting, and we have to be in position to address that risk should it become really a threat to—should it create a threat of more persistent, longer-term inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we think our policy is doing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s putting us in a position to be able to address the range of plausible outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess, as I said in my opening remarks, assuming the economy performs broadly as expected, the Committee judges that similar reductions in the pace of net asset purchases will likely be appropriate each month, and we’re prepared to deviate from that path if warranted by changes in the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: So, first of all, it is our job to—and we accept responsibility and accountability for inflation in the medium term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would want to assure people that we will use our tools as appropriate to get inflation under control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think it’s a good time to raise interest rates, though, because we want to see the labor market heal further.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: So “transitory” is a word that people have had different understandings of.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s why we, you know, we took a step back from “transitory.” We said “expected to be transitory,” first of all, to show uncertainty around that—we’ve always said that, by the way, in other contexts; we just hadn’t done it in the statement—but also to acknowledge, really, that it means different things to different people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then we added some language to really explain more what we’re talking about in paragraph two and paragraph three.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We said that “supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy have contributed to sizable price increases,” and we said, “Progress on vaccinations and an easing of supply constraints are expected to support continued gains in November 3, 2021 economic activity and employment as well as a reduction in inflation.” So we’re trying to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL explain what we mean and also acknowledging more uncertainty about “transitory.” So it’s, I mean, it’s become a word that’s attracted a lot of attention that maybe is distracting from our message, which we want to be as clear as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, the only other thing I would say is, look, we understand completely that it’s particularly people who are living paycheck to paycheck or seeing higher grocery costs, higher gasoline costs—when the winter comes, higher heating costs for their homes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand completely what they’re going through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we will use our tools over time to make sure that that doesn’t become a permanent feature of life.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, that’s one of our principal jobs, along with achieving maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s our commitment.

sentence: So we look at so many different things, and you make an overall judgment.

sentence: Bottlenecks should be abating.

sentence: We start to see that now with some of them, but, overall, they haven’t gotten better overall, and, you know, we’re very aware of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re thinking that time will tell us more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the meantime, we don’t think it’s time to raise rates now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, if we do conclude that it’s necessary to do so, then we’ll be patient, but we won’t hesitate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s not a decision for bank regulators or for any agency.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a decision for elected representatives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we feel that any role that we have—and we do think we have a role in climate change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It relates to our existing mandates, and our existing mandates are, really, prudential regulation of financial institutions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect them, and the public will expect us to expect them, to understand and be in a position to manage their risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s physical risk, and it’s transition risk for climate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, the large financial institutions are doing this already, and, you know, we think that’s right within our mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also a financial stability question, the overall stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, from that standpoint, we can do research.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can try to help understand what will the pathways be through which climate change effects the economy—both physical risk and transition risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we can do, and that’s what we will do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll do it well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Within the frame of our existing mandates, we’ll do it well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not the people who will decide the national strategy on climate change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That has to be elected people, and not so much us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We feel like we have that narrow mandate, and we will do it well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, you know, we—let me just say that this system, the ethics system we had in place had been in place for decades and had, as far as we know, served us well, and then that was no longer the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we had no moment of denial about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a group, we stepped in, and we took the actions that we took.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, within one FOMC cycle, we announced a new set of rules to, you know, to try to put us back where we need to be, which is, we need to have the complete trust of the American people that we’re working in their interest all the time—absolutely critical to our work, as it is for any government agency.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I feel like this called that into question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we reacted, I would characterize it, strongly and forcefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If there were other things that we could do that were reasonable, we would certainly do them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked me about blind trusts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the overall authority for ethics around these issues in the federal government is the Office of Government Ethics, OGE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they have a long-held position which is not favorable to blind trusts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They do not encourage them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They don’t think they’re effective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They think they’re cumbersome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they think there are better ways to get at the things that need to be done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are the things that we’re actually doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t know that there are any blind trusts, for that reason, because they are the, they’re the regulator.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They say this on their website, if you look.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of laws broken, you know, I November 3, 2021 asked the inspector general to look to see whether there were rules broken and whether there Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL were laws broken, and I won’t speculate on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that is with the inspector general now and, of course, out of my hands.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so, let me say what’s happened—and we’re very, very straightforward about it—is that inflation has come in higher than expected, and bottlenecks have been more persistent and more prevalent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see that just like everybody else does, and we see that they’re now on track to persist well into next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was not expected—not expected by us, not expected by other macro forecasters.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, let me say, you know, it’s difficult enough to just forecast the economy in normal times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When you’re talking about, you know, global supply chains in turmoil, it’s a whole different thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re talking about a pandemic that’s holding people out of the labor force for reasons that we can sample, but we don’t have a lot of experience with this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s very, very difficult to forecast and not easy to set policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have to set policy, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what we’re doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, so, to look at your question this way, I don’t think that we’re behind the curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I actually believe that policy is well positioned to address the range of plausible November 3, 2021 outcomes, and that’s what we need to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think it would be premature to raise rates today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL That’s not—I don’t think that’s controversial.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Certainly, I don’t know anyone arguing for that today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason is that there’s still ground to cover to get to maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t want to stop that when there’s good reason to think—there’s still good reason to think, although it’s been delayed, clearly, there’s good reason to think that the economy will reopen, particularly if we do get past, you know, significant outbreaks of COVID.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s when we’re really going to see what the characteristics of the labor market are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I think, you know, the bottlenecks that we’re seeing in global supply chains around goods and, frankly, now at our own domestic ports, because demand is stronger than the capacity of those ports—those things are going to work themselves out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a flexible economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll take some time, but, you know, it took—you know, the experts managed to create a vaccine faster than, certainly, than I expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think this stuff will work itself out over the course of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is my baseline understanding, and that’s a very widely held one among people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we are prepared for different eventualities, and we will use our tools to achieve price stability and maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to let the data lead us to where we need to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our policy will adapt—and has already adapted—to the changing understanding of inflation and of bottlenecks and the whole supply-side story—which is also partly a demand story.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our policy will continue to adapt as is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy is in quite a different place than when we tapered back in, I guess it was, 2013.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were much farther away from maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation was much lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is an economy where demand is very, very strong, very strong, and job openings substantially exceed the number of unemployed people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the need for further stimulus is far less than it was in 2013, where we still had quite a ways to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, after we began that taper, it was still many years before we reached what I would characterize as conditions consistent with maximum employment, let alone price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is quite a different situation, and, you know, the Committee unanimously felt today that we had met the test that we’d articulated, and this was appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is faster than, you know, than what people had expected six months ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s earlier and faster, and that’s because our, as I mentioned, our policy has been adapting to the situation as it evolves, as it’s clarifying itself, and that’s partly because we see inflation coming in higher—so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in terms of the balance sheet, those questions that you mention—we haven’t gone back to them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now that we’ve tapered, I expect that that’s exactly November 3, 2021 what we’ll do in coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll do it in an orderly fashion, and we’ll talk about Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL reinvestment and all those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t have to make decisions on those yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, typically, when we’re doing a new subject like that, we’ll have a series of briefings and discussions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we will now begin to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the effect of asset purchases on the economy, so, there’s a tremendous amount of research and scholarship on this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, you can kind of—you can find different people coming out with different views.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are two ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One, so you can’t lower rates—let’s say you can’t lower rates any further, hypothetically.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you can give forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can say, we’re going to keep the rates low for a period of time, either [for] a specific period, [or] until certain conditions are met.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The markets will do the math, and that’ll have an effect on longer-term borrowings even, you know, 10, 30 years out kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other thing you can do is, you just go buy those securities, buy longer-term securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will drive down longer-term rates and hold them lower, and, you know, rates right across the, right across the rate spectrum matter for borrowers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So lower rates encourage more borrowing, encourage more economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People—you can service your debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have more free cash flow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s not different from what we do at the short end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that was discussed long before anybody did it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was—I think Milton Friedman said that that was what you could do if you were pinned at the lower bound, many, many years ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, anyway, that’s how it’s supposed to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s quite hard to be precise about these things because, you know, you only have one economy, and you can’t run two different economies right next to each other and do a scientific experiment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But most people November 3, 2021 find—most of the findings are that it does support economic activity in the way that you would Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL expect, which is to say, at the margin, more economic activity with lower rates, which is why we do what we do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More accommodative financial conditions lead to more economic activity, over time, with a lag.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s the main finding I would say on QE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m not going to—I won’t have any—I will answer your question, Paul, but I’m not going to have any comment whatsoever on the renomination process at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say, though, that I have briefed Administration officials, and I’ve briefed people on Capitol Hill in detail about what we did and why we did it, and seeking their feedback, getting their reaction.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, this is—part of my job is—Congress has oversight over the Fed, and we take that very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you’re on our, one of the two committees that has oversight over us, then I’m in regular contact with you, probably.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, when something like this comes up, I’m on the phone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m offering to meet with you and explain it to you and answer your questions and identify any concerns people might have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s November 3, 2021 just part of my job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t talk about particular conversations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you can Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL assume I’ll always do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I certainly did it in this case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t have anything for you on supplemental leverage ratio right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are looking at ways to, if there are ways we can address liquidity issues through that channel.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also—we also have a—there’s a working group headed by [the] Treasury about, over Treasury [securities] markets, and what happened in the acute phase of the pandemic, and what structural things may need to be done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that would be part of that workstream, and I know that there’s a lot going on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not sure when that report will be out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s work under way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one of the many issues that are part of that, along with things like central clearing of Treasuries, greater central clearing, and, you know, many other ideas.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s important that we have a liquid Treasury [securities] market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a huge public benefit that we do, and, you know, I think we need to do those things that enable that, you know, while also assuring the safety and soundness of our largest financial institutions, who tend to be the main dealers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have to make sure that that’s always a first order of concern as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to answer who I spoke to at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just, I’m not going to give you any names, so don’t take that as a “yes” or “no.” I’m just not going to start down that road.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what’s happening is, people are leaving their jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re quitting their jobs in all-time-high numbers—but, in many cases, going back into employment and getting higher wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a lot of the higher wages you’re seeing are for job switchers rather than incumbents.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s just, that’s a sign of a really strong labor market, as opposed to people just running off and quitting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There have also been—there are a significant number of retirements, and we’ll just have to see what that means.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, toward the end of the last cycle, which was the longest in our recorded economic history, we did see labor force participation moving up well above what economists estimate was the trend, and part of that was people staying in the labor force or just not retiring at the rates they were expected to retire.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So maybe this was just catch-up on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I am a believer that, over time, you won’t know how far—you won’t know what can happen with labor force participation in advance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re just going to have to give it some time, because we saw that over and over again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are things that we can, where we can say, you know, this is where the limit is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Labor force participation is a much more flexible subject for me, and so I do think we need to be November 3, 2021 humble about what the limits are of labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we expect labor force Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL participation to pick up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know the pace at which it will do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in terms of full employment, as I discussed earlier, I think, at the very beginning of the recovery, the natural thing to do was to look back at labor conditions, labor market conditions in February of 2010, at the end of the longest expansion in our history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was so much to like about that labor market, a really historically good labor market—never perfect, but a good labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re in a different world now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a—it’s just very different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pandemic recession was the deepest, and the recovery has been the fastest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And wages didn’t really go down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, real incomes were more than fully replaced by fiscal policy [support].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of this is completely unusual.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, an economy where inflation was driven by services is now inflation where—all the inflation is in goods, which have had negative inflation for a quarter-century.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you ask about full employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we have to—I’m very open to the thought that it’s going to be an empirical question of where it is located, and we’re just going to learn more and more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look back, the three-, six-, and nine-month average job creation is between 550,000 and 600,000.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you think of that as a stronger—you don’t have to think back to the million-job months of June and July.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can just think, okay, 550 to 600—if we should get back on that path, then we would be making good progress, and we like to see that, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So November 3, 2021 we’ll know so much more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, believe me, we understand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a different world in so many Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re very open to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.
